title: A test of three hypotheses for latitudinal segregation of the sexes in wintering birds
abstract: Three hypotheses have been proposed to explain sexual differences in wintering latitude for different bird species: (1) intersexual behavioral dominance leads the subordinate sex to migrate farther to avoid competition; (2) intrasexual selection favors those individuals of one sex that arrive earlier and thus selects for wintering closer to the breeding ground; and (3) sexual differences in physiological tolerance allow the larger sex to survive harsher climates. Using sex, age, date, and location data from specimens collected south of the breeding range in the western hemisphere, I tested predictions of these hypotheses for two scolopacid shorebirds showing reverse sexual size dimorphism, the red phalarope, Phalaropus fulicarius, and the sanderling, Calidris alba. Neither red phalaropes nor adult sanderlings showed any sexual difference in wintering latitude. First-winter male sanderlings tended to winter farther south than first-winter females. Combined with comparative data from other species of shorebirds and passerines, these results are consistent only with hypothesis 2.

abstract.text: Three hypotheses have been proposed to explain sexual differences in wintering latitude for different bird species: (1) intersexual behavioral dominance leads the subordinate sex to migrate farther to avoid competition; (2) intrasexual selection favors those individuals of one sex that arrive earlier and thus selects for wintering closer to the breeding ground; and (3) sexual differences in physiological tolerance allow the larger sex to survive harsher climates. Using sex, age, date, and location data from specimens collected south of the breeding range in the western hemisphere, I tested predictions of these hypotheses for two scolopacid shorebirds showing reverse sexual size dimorphism, the red phalarope, Phalaropus fulicarius, and the sanderling, Calidris alba. Neither red phalaropes nor adult sanderlings showed any sexual difference in wintering latitude. First-winter male sanderlings tended to winter farther south than first-winter females. Combined with comparative data from other species of shorebirds and passerines, these results are consistent only with hypothesis 2.

body_text.text: Bird populations often show elaborate migration patterns involving sexual differences in the timing of movements or in geographic distributions during the nonbreeding season (Mayr 1939; Bellrose et al. 1961; King et al. 1965; Ketterson and Nolan 1976; Jaeger et al. 1979; Ketterson and Nolan 1979) . Differences in timing usually are linked to male and female roles in breeding and parental behavior (e.g. Connors et al. 1979) . What factors underlie differences in winter distribution, however, are not nearly so clear.

Three distinct hypotheses have been developed to explain why males and females from the same population might have different winter distributions: (1) intersexual competition for winter resources leads the subordinate sex to migrate beyond the winter distribution of the dominant sex (Gauthreaux 1978; Ketterson 1979 ; Ketterson and Nolan 1979) ; (2) intrasexual selection confers a reproductive advantage upon individuals of one sex, usually males, that winter closer to the breeding ground because they can arrive earlier in the breeding season (summarized in Ketterson and Nolan 1976) ; and (3) physiological limitations related to body size (greater cold tolerance and ability to fast) permit the larger sex to winter in more rigorous climates (Ketterson and Nolan 1976, 1979; Ketterson and King 1977) . These hypotheses are not mutually exclusive. In fact, Ketterson and Nolan (1979) propose that the pronounced geographic variation in winter sex ratio of dark-eyed juncos, Junco hyemalis, results from a complex interaction among all three proposed mechanisms.

As King et al. (1965) argue, however, testing hypotheses for these differential migration patterns requires a broad comparative base. In this paper I present data on the winter distributions of two scolopacid shorebirds, the sanderling, Calidris alba Pallas, and the red phalarope, Phalaropusfulicarius Linneaus.

These two shorebirds contrast with other species studied intensively to date in a set of characteristics important to 0008-4301/81/081527-08$01 . OO/O 01981 National Research Council of CanadaIConseil national de recherches du Canada Can. J. Zool. Downloaded from cdnsciencepub.com by UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN on 10/07/21

For personal use only. the hypotheses outlined above. First, both shorebirds show reverse sexual size dimorphism, with females larger than males. Second, both breed in the unusual mating system of facultative sequential polyandry (Parmelee and Payne 1973; Schamel and Tracey 1977) . Finally, the sexes of both arrive simultaneously on the breeding ground (Parmelee 1970; Connors et al. 1979) . Because there is some disagreement in the literature on this latter point for red phalaropes (compare Kistchinski 1975; Connors et al. 1979; Ridley 1980 ), I present original data on arrival times gathered during a multiyear censusing program from two red phalarope breeding sites in northern Alaska.

Finally, to expand the comparative data base still further, I review published data on winter distributions of the sexes in three other sandpiper species in which latitudinal segregation is known or suspected. These are the western sandpiper, Calidris mauri, the least sandpiper, C . minutilla, and the ruff, Philomachus pugnax. Although closely related to sanderlings, these species differ in breeding social system and therefore offer a valuable comparative perspective.

I obtained data on sex, age, location, and date of collection for 1492 sanderlings and 655 red phalaropes collected throughout the western hemisphere south of each species' breeding range (for sources see Acknowledgments). From each source of species I used all records for which sex, date, and location were available. Because winter residency is the critical period for testing the hypotheses outlined above (see Ketterson and Nolan 1979) , I eliminated specimens taken during migration. On the basis of data from a color-banded wintering sanderling population in central coastal California (Myers 1980) , this period extends in sanderlings from October to March for adults and November to March for first-winter birds. Comparable data are not available for red phalaropes so I assumed that their schedule was similar. Out of the total set of specimen records examined, this culling left 402 sanderlings and 180 red phalaropes for analysis (Table 1) . Birds of both known and unknown ages were considered.

Those I examined (Table 1) I aged using criteria in Palmer (1968) and Prater et al. (1977) . For those I did not examine I accepted the age-class assigned by the institution or collaborator providing the data. Because of difficulties in discriminating first-winter from adult shorebirds, I analyzed these two data sets separately as well as together. For neither species is there any reason to suspect a sex-related collection bias during the winter that would vary systematically among regions. Both are plumage monomorphic in winter. Even if an overall sex bias in collecting occurred, without regional variation in the bias the data should reveal changes in the relative abundance of the two sexes reliably. I assume that any errors in sexing specimens also lack regional trends. I ran separate analyses on adults, on first-winter birds, and on both age classes combined. For each, male and female (Nie et al. 1975) . Unless otherwise stated, all tests are two-tailed.

Beginning each season before the arrival of either sex, we censused all shorebirds including red phalaropes every 5 days at two sites on the arctic coastal plain of northern Alaska. At various times up to five others were also involved in this fieldwork. One site lay adjacent to the Arctic Ocean at Barrow (71'18' N, 156"42' W) and the other was approximately l00km to the south and inland at Atkasook (70'27' N, 157"19' W). Data were gathered at Barrow from 1976 to 1980 and at Atkasook from 1977 to 1979. For details of the censusing technique and descriptions of the areas see Comors et al. (1979) and Myers and Pitelka (1980) . Briefly, in each census a single observer walked a systematic zigzag path along each of 10 (Barrow) or 14 (Atkasook) 1000-m X 100-m transects marked permanently by a single row of stakes down the long axis at 50-m intervals. The path brought the observer to within 25 m of all locations on the transect. Passage from one stake to the next was timed to 3-4 min so that each transect took 1-1.5 h. The low stature of tundra vegetation and tameness of birds allowed detection of virtually all nonincubating phalaropes. As the subject for this analysis, migratory arrival, precedes nesting, incubating birds do not affect the data presented here.
body_text.section: Arrival times of male versus female red phalaropes

body_text.text: Collection locations for the sanderling specimens reviewed ranged between 42" S and 52" N with a median collection latitude of 30°N. Of the winter specimens, 60% were adults (Table 1 ). There was no difference between latitudinal distributions of adults and firstwinter birds, either for the entire set of aged birds or for Can. J. body_text.section: Winter distribution of adult andjrst-winter birds

body_text.text: For winter-collected red phalaropes, the distribution of specimens spanned from 65" S to 61" N with a median latitude of 33"N. Again, there was no difference between adult and first-winter birds: for the entire set of aged birds U = 2059, N = 132, P > 0.62; for the smaller set I examined, U = 238, N = 45, P > 0.83.
body_text.section: Winter distribution of adult andjrst-winter birds

body_text.text: The winter distributions of the sexes within sanderlings and within red phalaropes are remarkably similar (Fig. 1) . The strong mode in the northern hemisphere for both species is due in part to the geographic distribution of collecting activities (see Discussion).
body_text.section: Winter distribution of males versus females

body_text.text: Neither adult sanderlings nor adult red phalaropes showed any difference between the sexes in winter distribution (Table 2) . First-winter male and female red phalaropes again failed to reveal any sexual divergence in wintering latitude(U = 2933, N = 167, P > 0.73). A comparison of first-year sanderling males with first-year sanderling females, however, indicated that first-year males winter somewhat south of females: a median winter latitude of 28"N for males versus 33"N for females (compared with 29' N for both male and female adults; Fig. 2 ). This pattern is statistically significant with the larger data set of all aged specimens (Table 2) , and it is almost significant within those I aged myself (U = 372, N = 65, P -0.052).
body_text.section: Winter distribution of males versus females

body_text.text: Red phalaropes begin to appear on the coastal plain tundra near Atkasook as early as the final 5 days in May but more typically in the beginning of June (Table 3) . Their arrival at Barrow commences 5-10 days later and peaks during the period 10-14 June. At both sites, males and females appear simultaneously. Although there is some variation in the relative abundance of males versus females, no consistent pattern emerges on sexual differences in arrival schedule. For example, at Barrow males were more abundant along the census transects for the first two sampling periods after arrival began for 2 of the 5 years sampled, whereas females were more numerous the other three. The striking fact, however, is how parallel the changes in their abundance are. My observations of red phalaropes in both study areas but away from the sampled transects are consistent with these data. Typically the first sighting of red phalaropes during a particular year involve birds of both sexes together in pairs or small flocks flying over the tundra.
body_text.section: Arrival schedule of red phalaropes in northern Alaska

body_text.text: Sanderlings breed only sporadically at Barrow and not at all near Atkasook. Thus I have no census data Can. J. Zool. Downloaded from cdnsciencepub.com by UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN on 10/07/21
body_text.section: Arrival schedule of red phalaropes in northern Alaska

body_text.text: For personal use only. from these sites to compare with published observations (Parmelee 1970) . Nevertheless, small flocks of sanderlings move past the Barrow area early in June and, consistent with Parmelee (1970) , both sexes are present (personal observation; F. A. Pitelka, personal communication).
body_text.section: Arrival schedule of red phalaropes in northern Alaska

body_text.text: Neither sanderlings nor red phalaropes show strong latitudinal segregation of the sexes during the nonbreed-ding season. Indeed, the only significant difference apparent is between first-winter male and first-winter female sanderlings (discussed below). These findings stand in marked contrast to the geographic separation reported for other species, including three shorebirds, two passerines, and one woodpecker (Table 4) . At issue is whether any of the three hypotheses outlined in the Introduction predict both the specific results for sanderlings and red phalaropes as well as the overall pattern of Table 4 . Such need not be the case, as the mechanisms posited by the hypotheses may act together instead of singly (see Ketterson and Nolan 1979) or not at all. But it is far easier to begin by looking for simple answers.

In four of eight cases summarized in Table 4 , males are larger than females. In each of these, males also winter further north, as predicted by hypotheses 1 and 3, and not contradictory to hypothesis 2. Two species with reverse sexual size dimorphism (female larger than males), however, show males wintering further north. Both the behavioral dominance (1) and physiological (3) hypotheses predict that females of these species and of red phalaropes and sanderlings should winter further north (Gauthreaux 1978; Ketterson and Nolan 1979) .

Predictions of the physiological hypothesis are plausible only if individuals encounter cold temperatures or run the risk of prolonged fasting. All the shorebird species in question span broad latitudinal ranges in their winter distributions, including regions above 40" N. Although they may not encounter conditions as severe as those faced by dark-eyed juncos in interior North America (Ketterson and Nolan 1976) , shorebird species wintering at these latitudes undergo periods of lowered food Can. J. Zool. Downloaded from cdnsciencepub.com by UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN on 10/07/21 For personal use only. availability and run the risk of starving (Ash 1964; Pienkowski et al. 1979) . Moreover, there appears to be geographic variation in the likelihood of prolonged fasting, with conditions improving southward (Dick and Pienkowski 1979) .

For the behavioral dominance model these predictions rest on the assumption that reverse sexual size dimorphism confers dominance on females. Some evidence is available from shorebirds to examine this assumption, but none from the species in question. In the spotted sandpiper, Actites macularia (Maxon and Oring 1980) , and the jacana, Jacana spinosa (D. A. Jenni, personal communication), females are both larger than males and dominant to males in all behavioral interactions. Size predicts intra-and inter-specific dominance in many other bird species (Morse 1974; Gauthreaux 1978; Ketterson 1979) .

With respect to hypothesis 2, in each species in which males reach the breeding grounds first, males also winter farther north. In both known cases of simultaneous arrival, males and females show no latitudinal segregation in winter (see below on first-winter sanderlings). Unfortunately, the arrival schedule of one species is unknown (Table 4) .

Taken as a whole, this comparison supports hypothesis 2. As such, it does not imply that intersexual competition for resources does not exist in winter, nor that there are not physiological differences in cold tolerance or fasting ability related to body size. Instead, it argues that to predict latitudinal segregation of the sexes, information about arrival schedules is both necessary and sufficient.

The statistical difference between first-winter male and first-winter female sanderlings appears inconsistent Can. J. Zool. Downloaded from cdnsciencepub.com by UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN on 10/07/21 For personal use only. with hypothesis 2. GI] one hand, while statistically significant, the difference is small (Fig. 2) compared with differences observed in other species, especially the dark-eyed junco (Ketterson and Nolan 1976) and the ruff, Philomachus pugnax (Greenhalgh 1968 ). Moreover, because the adult sanderling distributions so clearly contradict hypotheses 1 and 3, I favor an alternative, even if post-hoc, interpretation for the differences within first-winter birds. If sanderling males show delayed maturity, then by hypothesis 2 first-winter males should winter farther south. This follows because without breeding, there would be no reason for a first-winter male to migrate north in the breeding season, and certainly not to appear among the first arrivals, so it could winter farther south than first-winter females (see below concerning ideal winter distribution). Individuals of many shorebird species, including sanderlings, remain south of their breeding grounds during the nesting season. Unfortunately, in only a few are data sufficient to test for delayed maturity (Eliot et al. 1976; Myers 1981) , and the sanderling is not among them. I predict that sanderling males show delayed maturity compared with females and do not mate in their first summer after hatching.

My data on arrival times of red phalaropes run counter to those of Ridley (1980) and also to Gauthreaux's citation of Kistchinski (1975) . Ridley's data are restricted to 1 year's observation and deal with no more than 25 locally breeding pairs. Further, and more importantly, his observations began on 16 June even though he estimated egg laying began as early as 10 June. Thus Ridley did not witness arrival. He asserted that females arrived first because the sex ratio only reached parity by 27 June; until then females outnumbered male;. Instead of reflecting different arrival dates, this may instead have resulted from the onset of female departure (which precedes male departure in this species; Connors et al. 1979) coupled with an overall female bias in local sex ratio during Ridley's 1 year of study.

Considerable interyear variation can occur in both sex ratio and arrival schedule ( Table 3) . Kistchinski ( 1975) observed similar fluctuations: the modal pattern apparently varied from year to year and among areas, and no consistent pattern could be identified with respect to sexual differences in arrival times (contra Gauthreaux 1978) .

The specimens used to analyze winter distributions of both sanderling and red phalarope comprise a modest sample, limited by size and by assumptions and potential errors inherent in museum series (see Methods). They are what is available now. The weakest link is the degree to which the geography of collecting has emphasized north temperate distributions (Figs. 1, 2) . To an unknown degree the shape of those distributions reflects collector activities rather than bird distribution. If nothing else, this emphasizes the continuing need for building museum series even of common species. But fortunately, the analysis does not depend upon a distribution of samples proportional to the underlying geographic distribution of the species; it is based instead on relative comparisons between the sexes. Thus despite limitations in these data, the analysis should have revealed winter sexual segregation were the patterns as conspicuous as those reported for other species.

It is also clear that studies of arrival schedules are needed for other species. The pattern in some is beyond debate, for example, the ruff (Hogan-Warburg 1966) . But in each, good documentation of sex-specific arrival schedules is complicated by sexual differences in conspicuousness and by the need for data describing population trends rather than individual case histories. As the goal of work on winter sexual segregation shifts from testing for its presence to examining why species differ in degree (see below), the desirability of timing studies will rise.

B; hypothesis 2, selective forces responsible for geographic segregation of the sexes in winter are related to differences in arrival time on the breeding ground. Sexually staggered arrival might occur for two reasons. First, the sexes might differ simply in the phenology of resource use. Second, there may be sexual differences in the degree of intrasexual competition for breeding sites, related to the clear importance of priority in obtaining better breeding territories (HildCn 1979) . The most likely interpretation combines these two arguments: In species with territorial defense, the sex establishing territories should arrive as early as possible; how early relative to breeding is set by the availability of food. The other sex, in contrast, will delay until the onset of nesting, modified by the degree to which it also experiences intrasexual competition for breeding sites. This interpretation makes two predictions: (i) nontemtorial species (e.g. phalaropes) should not show staggered arrival schedules; and (ii) for species with similar, territorial breeding social systems, staggering should decrease with increasing latitude because of increased breeding season compression. Sanderlings' lack of staggering may thus result from their high arctic breeding distribution (also see below).

Although supported by the current data set, hypothesis 2 nevertheless seems a weak argument: Why couldn't individuals simply depart earlier? What is the magnitude of advantage gained by wintering, on average, a few degrees farther north? It may develop that some species show one pattern and others the alternative, and that this alternation only becomes apparent with a larger comparative data set. It is unlikely that early departure would be Can. J. Zool. Downloaded from cdnsciencepub.com by UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN on 10/07/21
For personal use only.

as costly in species that move opportunistically through their winter range as it would be in those with sedentary winter populations, where winter survivorship might be highly sensitive to knowledge of local resource conditions.

In considering possible trade-offs between early departure versus closer wintering, it is important to recognize that the logic of hypothesis 2 is not that one sex should winter farther north than the other. Rather, it is that members of that sex should winter closer to the breeding ground than they would were there no intrasexual selection for early arrival. This implies some sort of ideal winter distribution for each sex. Under the null hypothesis, these distributions are sexually indistinguishable, but intrasexual selection leads one or both sexes to deviate from their ideals. Sexual asymmetry in the degree of intrasexual selection then leads to one sex wintering closer to the breeding ground.

Setting forth hypothesis 2 in this way may resolve some of its apparent weakness. Carried to its limit, it suggests that natural selection for early arrival should lead both to wintering as far north and leaving as early as possible. If this indeed is the case, then the phenomenon of winter sexual segregation should b e widespread among migrant species in which one sex defends a breeding temtory .

By implication, then, a species' social system becomes an important predictor of winter sexual segregation. Both red phalaropes and sanderlings stand out among the species in Table 4 as showing facultative sequential polyandry. Red phalaropes, moreover, are nontemtorial, and sanderlings, although territorial, breed at very low density compared with other sandpipers (Schamel and Tracey 1977; HildCn 1979) . These factors may lessen the importance of early arrival to males. Several other migratory shorebirds share one or the other of these characteristics and thus offer tests for this interpretation compared with the predictions related to resource phenologies outlined above. These species include mountain plover, Eupoda montana (Graul 1973) , dotterel, Eudromias morinella (Nethersole-Thompson 1973), Temminck's stint, Calidris temminckii (HildCn 1975) , northern phalarope, Phalaropus lobatus (HildCn and Vuolanto 1972) , and Wilson's phalarope, P . tricolor (Kagarise 1979 ). Temminck's stints are particularly interesting because (i) their mating system is comparable with sanderling's, (ii) males are smaller and arrive earlier than females ( 0 . HildCn, personal communication), and (iii) early males obtain better territories than do late males (Hildkn 1979) . This species should be compared for latitudinal segregation in winter with the spotted sandpiper, a simultaneously polyandrous species (Oring and Knudsen 1972) with females larger than males, female territorial defense, and females arriving before males (L. W. Oring, personal communication) . I predict that male Tem-minck's stints and female spotted sandpipers winter farther north.

BIBREF28.title: On multiple broods and the breeding strategy of arctic sanderlings
BIBREF28.raw_text: PARMELEE, D. F., and R. B. PAYNE. 1973. On multiple broods and the breeding strategy of arctic sanderlings. Ibis, 115: 218-226.

BIBREF32.raw_text: RIDLEY, M. W. 1980. The breeding behaviour and feeding ecology of Grey Phalaropes Phalaropus fulicarius in Svalbard. Ibis, 122: 210-226.

BIBREF33.raw_text: SCHAMEL, D., and D. TRACEY. 1977. Polyandry, replacement clutches, and site tenacity in the Red Phalarope (Phalaropus fulicarius) at Barrow, Alaska. Bird-Banding, 48: 314-325.

BIBREF34.raw_text: SCHMIDT, M. B., and P. J. Whitehouse. 1976. Moult and mensural data on Ruff in the Witwaterstrand. Ostrich, 47: 179-190.

BIBREF35.raw_text: SIEGEL, S. 1956. Nonparametric statistics for the behavioral sciences. McGraw Hill, New York.

BIBREF36.raw_text: SPAANS, A. 1976. Molt of flight and tail feathers of the least sandpiper in Surinam, South America. Bird-Banding, 47: 359-364.
